issue.title: Enable build on Windows
issue.body: The Makefile needs to be rewritten for Windows.

comment.body: I finally got it working in windows but it did require a bunch of updates to the POM file.  If you like I could submit a fix for this.

issue.title: Enable build on Windows
issue.body: The Makefile needs to be rewritten for Windows.

comment.body:
> I finally got it working in windows but it did require a bunch of updates to the POM file.  If you like I could submit a fix for this.

That would be very welcome!

issue.title: Enable build on Windows
issue.body: The Makefile needs to be rewritten for Windows.

comment.body:
Working POM file:

Directions:   
1.  Build liboqs on Windows as per regular instructions included for liboqs.  I like using cmake-gui to make the windows solution files.   You can get cmake (that comes with cmake-gui) here:  https://cmake.org/download/
  -a) Set cmake source code to the location where you cloned the main liboqs repository
  -b) Set where to build binary files wherever you want the output.   This location is important for building with liboqs-java.
  -c) Make sure you add an entry called BUILD_SHARED_LIBS as a BOOL and checkmark it (this will ensure the liboqs.dll is built)
  -d) Generate the solution files, and build with VC 2019.  The main liboqs.sln will be in the folder you specify in 1b above.
  -e) Open the liboqs.sln file in visual studio and compile the project.   liboqs.dll will be in the output folder from 1b in a folder called bin (and probably under a Debug or Release folder).   

2.  To build Liboqs-java on Windows:
 -a) Open an "x64 Native Tools Command Prompt for VS 2019" (or whatever version of VS code you have).  You can find it in the start menu folder for Visual Studio 2019.  
 -b) In the x64 Native Tools Command Prompt cd to the directory where liboqs-java was cloned
 -c) Issue the command "mvn package -P windows "-Dliboqs.include.dir=[path to liboqs include dir]" "-Dliboqs.lib.dir=[path to liboqs lib dir]
      where
          [path to liboqs include dir] is in the path from 1b inside the include folder.  
          [path to liboqs lib dir] is in the path from 1b inside the lib folder.
  -d) If all is well, the oqs-jni.dll and liboqs-java.jar should be in the liboqs-java projects target folder.  

Here a tested POM file (Test by two people at Entrust with Visual Studio 2019).

[pom.zip](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-java/files/14730334/pom.zip)

issue.title: How to run quantum-safe KEM algorithms?
issue.body:
Hi there,

I am trying to use the quantum-safe KEM algorithms (specifically mlkem512) in a simple example to encapsulate/decapsulate a symmetric key, aes-256, that in turn will be used to encrypt/decrypt a text file. I am not sure how to run any of these KEM algorithms on the command line in my Ubuntu terminal. I was able to run a simple example of signing a text file with falcon512 but am getting errors when I try the KEM example.

**Code version/branch I am using:**
I managed to follow the instructions for cloning and installing https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider.git correctly. 

**$ openssl list -providers**
Providers:
  default
    name: OpenSSL Default Provider
    version: 3.0.10
    status: active
  oqsprovider
    name: OpenSSL OQS Provider
    version: 0.5.4-dev
    status: active

**OpenSSL version running on my machine:**
**$ openssl version**
OpenSSL 3.0.10 1 Aug 2023 (Library: OpenSSL 3.0.10 1 Aug 2023)

**Attempted KEM commands with errors:**
**$openssl genpkey -algorithm mlkem512 -out sk.key**
Error writing key
40A72FFF707A0000:error:1D800065:ENCODER routines:OSSL_ENCODER_to_bio:reason(101):../crypto/encode_decode/encoder_lib.c:55:No encoders were found. For standard encoders you need at least one of the default or base providers available. Did you forget to load them?
40A72FFF707A0000:error:04800073:PEM routines:do_pk8pkey:error converting private key:../crypto/pem/pem_pk8.c:133:

**$ openssl genpkey -aes-256-cbc -algorithm mlkem512 -out sk.pem**
Error writing key
40B75A1CEE7C0000:error:1D800065:ENCODER routines:OSSL_ENCODER_to_bio:reason(101):../crypto/encode_decode/encoder_lib.c:55:No encoders were found. For standard encoders you need at least one of the default or base providers available. Did you forget to load them?
40B75A1CEE7C0000:error:04800073:PEM routines:do_pk8pkey:error converting private key:../crypto/pem/pem_pk8.c:133:

Please could you let me know what exactly I am doing incorrectly and how to run my KEM example. Thanks.

comment.body:
@ashman-p: Thanks for the reply. This still doesn't work though; I think the issue is what @baentsch mentioned.

@baentsch: I think this is indeed the problem because when I run `openssl list -encoders`, none of the KEM algorithms come up. I made the mistake of thinking that running `fullbuild.sh` would build the complete software stack with all functionality operational. Please could you let me know how to go about activating these KEM encoders? Do I need to rebuild? Where exactly do I set these OQS_KEM_ENCODERS to "ON"? Thanks.

comment.body:
> Where exactly do I set these OQS_KEM_ENCODERS to "ON"?

This is all documented in https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/blob/main/CONFIGURE.md

May be easily set by convenience envvar  here https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/blob/66ee77021b7ae35929e4659ac3f4b1e7642ddc67/scripts/fullbuild.sh#L7

issue.title: 0.10.0 release
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
Release of liboqs 0.10.0.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->
Completes https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/milestone/23.

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [Yes] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [Yes] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in fully supported downstream projects dependent on these, i.e., [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body:
> Thanks Michael for the typo fix! If you are willing to do the merge and release, go ahead, not sure I'll get to it in the next few days.

Done. I hope I got everything right. Good luck with RWC24!
